The sequence of natural numbers some 0, some 1, ...

name: Stream'.Seq.nats
docString: The sequence of natural numbers some 0, some 1, ...

For all natural numbers `n`, the product of `n` and `n-1` is an even number. Equivalently, the product of two consecutive natural numbers is an even number.

name: Nat.even_mul_self_pred
docString: For all natural numbers `n`, the product of `n` and `n-1` is an even number. Equivalently, the product of two consecutive natural numbers is an even number.

This theorem states that for every natural number `n`, the successor of `n` is equal to `n` plus one. In other words, it enforces the standard mathematical principle that adding one to a natural number gives you the next consecutive natural number.

name: Nat.succ_eq_add_one
docString: This theorem states that for every natural number `n`, the successor of `n` is equal to `n` plus one. In other words, it enforces the standard mathematical principle that adding one to a natural number gives you the next consecutive natural number.

For all natural numbers n, n ≤ n+1.

statement: theorem Nat.le_succ : ∀ (n : ℕ), n ≤ n.succ := by sorry
name: Nat.le_succ
description: This theorem states that for any natural number `n`, `n` is less than or equal to its successor (`n + 1`). That means, in any situation where you have a natural number, it will always be less than or equal to the next natural number.
concise-description: For all natural numbers n, n ≤ n+1.

The stream of natural numbers: `Stream'.get n Stream'.nats = n`.

name: Stream'.nats
docString: The stream of natural numbers: `Stream'.get n Stream'.nats = n`.

For all natural numbers n, (n + 1) divides the central binomial coefficient n.centralBinom.

name: Nat.succ_dvd_centralBinom
docString: For all natural numbers n, (n + 1) divides the central binomial coefficient n.centralBinom.

This theorem states that for any natural number `n`, the sum of `1` and `n` is equal to the successor of `n`. In more mathematical terms, the theorem is saying that for all natural numbers `n`, 1 + n = n + 1, where "succ" denotes the successor function (i.e., the function that gives the next natural number). This corresponds to the intuitive concept of adding one to a number to get the next number.

name: Nat.one_add
docString: This theorem states that for any natural number `n`, the sum of `1` and `n` is equal to the successor of `n`. In more mathematical terms, the theorem is saying that for all natural numbers `n`, 1 + n = n + 1, where "succ" denotes the successor function (i.e., the function that gives the next natural number). This corresponds to the intuitive concept of adding one to a number to get the next number.

The prime factors of a natural number as a finset.

name: Nat.primeFactors
docString: The prime factors of a natural number as a finset.

For every natural number n, the cardinality of the set of natural numbers up to n's successor is the successor of the cardinality of the set of natural numbers up to n.

name: Cardinal.nat_succ
docString: For every natural number n, the cardinality of the set of natural numbers up to n's successor is the successor of the cardinality of the set of natural numbers up to n.

This theorem states that for any natural number `n`, adding one to `n` is equivalent to the successor of `n`. In other words, for any number `n`, `n + 1` is the same as the next number after `n` in the sequence of natural numbers. This is a fundamental property of natural numbers in the Peano postulates.

name: Num.add_one
docString: This theorem states that for any natural number `n`, adding one to `n` is equivalent to the successor of `n`. In other words, for any number `n`, `n + 1` is the same as the next number after `n` in the sequence of natural numbers. This is a fundamental property of natural numbers in the Peano postulates.

The nth-harmonic number defined as a finset sum of consecutive reciprocals.

name: harmonic
docString: The nth-harmonic number defined as a finset sum of consecutive reciprocals.

For all natural numbers n, the (n+2)-th Fibonacci number is equal to the sum of the n-th and (n+1)-th Fibonacci numbers.

name: Nat.fib_add_two
docString: For all natural numbers n, the (n+2)-th Fibonacci number is equal to the sum of the n-th and (n+1)-th Fibonacci numbers.

This theorem states that for all natural numbers `n`, the product of `n` and `n - 1` is an even number. In mathematical terms, this theorem can be written as: "∀ n ∈ ℕ, n*(n - 1) is even." Here, a number is considered even if it can be expressed as twice another number, in this case, n*(n - 1) = 2*r for some `r`.

name: Nat.even_mul_self_pred
docString: This theorem states that for all natural numbers `n`, the product of `n` and `n - 1` is an even number. In mathematical terms, this theorem can be written as: "∀ n ∈ ℕ, n*(n - 1) is even." Here, a number is considered even if it can be expressed as twice another number, in this case, n*(n - 1) = 2*r for some `r`.

name: PNat.factorMultiset
docString: The prime factors of n, regarded as a multiset

The product of the prime factors of `n` that are less than `N` is an `N`-smooth number.

type: ∀ (n N : ℕ), List.prod (List.filter (fun x => decide (x < N)) (Nat.factors n)) ∈ Nat.smoothNumbers N
name: Nat.prod_mem_smoothNumbers
docString: The product of the prime factors of `n` that are less than `N` is an `N`-smooth number.
